description:
But first the head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, has again said that Greece won't be given special treatment over its debts. Ms Lagarde is meeting Eurogroup finance ministers as pressure builds on Athens to accept reforms, to prevent it defaulting on a major loan at the end of the month. And she stressed that Greece still had to make changes.

"As much as we want the programme to be credible, we are flexible in its implementation. So, credible, flexible and in the case of Greece, we believe that the pensions have to be reformed and everybody knows that."

The Greek government has refused to consider big cuts to pensions. Earlier the German Chancellor Angela Merkel said a deal with Greece was still possible. There is, though, an anxious mood among these residents in Athens.

"I don't know where this is headed, but it has lasted way too long. At some point, finally something has to happen: either they accept the proposal or they find a compromise, but they really need to do something because we have reached a point for both young and old, all of us, where our patience has run out and our hope is dying."
